questions.text: A 12 year-old patient presented with bleeding from ear, pain, tinnitus and increasing deafness. Examination revealed red swelling/mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on pressure with pneumatic speculum. Treatments for her include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Interferons) because they are not a standard treatment for the described condition, which is most likely a glomus tympanicum tumor. A glomus tympanicum is a vascular tumor arising from the paraganglionic cells of the middle ear. It presents with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a red retrotympanic mass that blanches with pneumatic otoscopy (Brown’s sign). Treatment involves surgery, preoperative embolization, and radiotherapy for unresectable cases, but interferons are not commonly used. Interferons are not a standard treatment for glomus tympanicum tumors. They are used in some vascular tumors (like hemangiomas), but not in glomus tumors where surgery and embolization are preferred. Incorrect Options: Option A (Preoperative Embolization) Glomus tumors are highly vascular, so embolization is done before surgery to reduce bleeding risk. It involves occluding the feeding arteries, typically via angiographic embolization. Option B (Radiotherapy) Used in patients who are not surgical candidates (e.g., elderly or inoperable tumors). It controls tumor growth but does not remove the tumor completely. Option C (Surgery) Definitive treatment for glomus tympanicum is surgical excision. The approach depends on tumor size and extent of involvement.

questions.text: Schwartz operation is also called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Cortical Mastoidectomy) because Schwartz operation is another name for cortical mastoidectomy, a surgical procedure used to drain infections from the mastoid air cells. Schwartz operation (Cortical Mastoidectomy) is performed to treat mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, or chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) without cholesteatoma. The posterior wall of the external auditory canal is preserved, differentiating it from more extensive mastoid surgeries. The primary goal is removal of diseased mastoid air cells while maintaining ear structures. Incorrect Options: Option B (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy) In modified radical mastoidectomy, the posterior wall of the external auditory canal is removed, creating a common cavity between the mastoid and middle ear. This is done in cholesteatoma cases where disease clearance is necessary. Option C (Radical Mastoidectomy) In radical mastoidectomy, both the posterior canal wall and tympanic membrane are removed, leading to complete exteriorization of the mastoid and middle ear. Used for extensive cholesteatoma and irreversible middle ear disease. Option D (Fenestration Operation) Fenestration operation was historically used for otosclerosis before the development of stapedectomy. It involves creating a new opening in the lateral semicircular canal to improve hearing. It is unrelated to mastoidectomy procedures.

questions.text: A 30 years old male is having Attic cholesteatoma of left ear with lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. Which of the following will be the operation of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Canal Wall Down Mastoidectomy) because attic cholesteatoma with lateral sinus thrombophlebitis indicates an extensive disease requiring complete removal of infected and cholesteatomatous tissue while preventing further complications. Why is Canal Wall Down Mastoidectomy (Option C) Correct? Attic cholesteatoma is an aggressive disease that can erode the ossicles, mastoid air cells, and even intracranial structures. Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis is a serious complication caused by the spread of infection from the middle ear or mastoid, leading to venous sinus thrombosis and possible sepsis. Canal Wall Down Mastoidectomy (CWDM) removes the posterior bony canal wall, creating a mastoid cavity that is exteriorized for better postoperative drainage and surveillance. This procedure is preferred in cases of extensive cholesteatoma, intracranial complications, or poor middle ear ventilation. Incorrect Options: Option A (Intact Canal Wall Mastoidectomy) Also known as Canal Wall Up Mastoidectomy, this procedure preserves the posterior canal wall and is used for less extensive disease. In this case, the presence of sinus thrombophlebitis requires aggressive disease clearance, making this option unsuitable. Option B (Simple Mastoidectomy with Tympanoplasty) Simple mastoidectomy only removes infected mastoid air cells but does not adequately address cholesteatoma. Tympanoplasty aims at reconstruction of the middle ear, which is not the priority here due to the severe infection and complications. Option D (Mastoidectomy with Cavity Obliteration) Cavity obliteration is done to reduce the size of the mastoid cavity and improve healing. It is not the primary choice in active infection with lateral sinus thrombophlebitis, where extensive clearance is needed.

questions.text: The glomus tumor invasion of jugular bulb is diagnosed by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Jugular Venography) because glomus jugulare tumors originate from the paraganglionic cells of the jugular bulb, and jugular venography is the best modality to assess invasion of the jugular bulb and venous structures. Jugular venography is a specialized imaging technique that provides detailed visualization of the jugular bulb and venous structures. It helps detect tumor invasion into the jugular vein, which is critical for surgical planning. This imaging modality is particularly useful in identifying venous obstruction or thrombosis caused by tumor growth. Incorrect Options: Option A (Carotid Angiography) Carotid angiography helps assess vascular supply from the external and internal carotid arteries but does not specifically diagnose invasion of the jugular bulb. It is more useful for evaluating the vascular nature of the tumor. Option B (Vertebral Venous Venography) Vertebral venous venography is used to evaluate vertebral venous circulation, which may be secondarily affected, but it does not directly assess the jugular bulb. It is less specific compared to jugular venography. Option C (CT) CT scans with contrast can show bony destruction of the jugular foramen and tumor extent. However, it does not provide direct visualization of venous invasion like jugular venography does.

questions.text: Hallmark feature of mastoiditis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Sagging) because a hallmark feature of mastoiditis is sagging of the posterior superior canal wall or postauricular swelling, which indicates spread of infection from the middle ear to the mastoid air cells. Mastoiditis occurs when infection from otitis media spreads into the mastoid air cells, leading to inflammation, bone destruction, and abscess formation. The most characteristic clinical sign is sagging of the posterosuperior canal wall due to inflammation and pus collection in the mastoid bone. This sagging is observed on otoscopic examination and suggests bone erosion and advanced disease. Incorrect Options: Option B (Ear Discharge) Persistent or foul-smelling ear discharge (otorrhea) is common in mastoiditis but is not the hallmark feature. Discharge can also be seen in chronic otitis media and other ear infections. Option C (Ironing of Mastoid) Ironing out (flattening) of the postauricular fold occurs in advanced mastoiditis, but it is not the most specific or earliest feature. It results from subperiosteal abscess formation and soft tissue swelling. Option D (Tenderness) Mastoid tenderness is an early sign of mastoiditis but is not as specific as posterosuperior canal sagging. Tenderness can also be seen in other conditions like furunculosis and external otitis

questions.text: 'Gradenigo triad’ is characteristic of;
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Petrous Apicitis) because Gradenigo's Triad is a classic sign of petrous apicitis, which is a complication of chronic otitis media where infection spreads to the petrous apex of the temporal bone. Gradenigo’s Triad consists of: Otitis media (chronic ear infection) Ipsilateral abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy (leading to diplopia) Retro-orbital pain due to irritation of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) The petrous apex is located near these cranial nerves, so infection can cause cranial neuropathies. The condition occurs due to osteitis and abscess formation in the petrous apex and is commonly associated with chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Incorrect Options: Option B (Facial Nerve Paralysis) Facial nerve paralysis (CN VII) can be a complication of otitis media or mastoiditis, but it is not part of Gradenigo's Triad. Gradenigo’s syndrome primarily affects CN V (trigeminal nerve) and CN VI (abducens nerve), not CN VII. Option C (Subperiosteal Abscess) Subperiosteal abscess occurs when infection spreads from the mastoid to the periosteum, leading to postauricular swelling and tenderness. It does not involve abducens nerve palsy or retro-orbital pain, making it unrelated to Gradenigo's Triad. Option D (Labyrinthine Fistula) Labyrinthine fistula is an abnormal opening between the inner ear and middle ear, often due to cholesteatoma, leading to vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. It does not affect the abducens or trigeminal nerves, so it does not cause Gradenigo’s Triad.

questions.text: Processus cochleariformis is related to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Tendon of Tensor Tympani) because the Processus Cochleariformis is a bony projection in the middle ear through which the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle passes before attaching to the handle of the malleus. The tensor tympani muscle is responsible for dampening loud sounds by pulling on the malleus, reducing excessive vibrations of the tympanic membrane. The Processus Cochleariformis acts as a pulley-like structure, guiding the tensor tympani tendon before it inserts into the handle of the malleus. This small bony prominence is located above the cochlear promontory in the middle ear cavity. Incorrect Options: Option B (Basal Turn of Cochlea) The basal turn of the cochlea is part of the inner ear, involved in high-frequency sound detection. The Processus Cochleariformis is a middle ear structure, unrelated to the cochlear turns. Option C (Handle of Malleus) While the tensor tympani tendon attaches to the handle of the malleus, the Processus Cochleariformis itself does not directly relate to it. The Processus Cochleariformis primarily serves as a support and guiding structure for the tensor tympani tendon. Option D (Incus) The incus is one of the middle ear ossicles that transmits vibrations from the malleus to the stapes. The Processus Cochleariformis has no direct anatomical or functional relation to the incus.

choices.text: Cone of light is absent or interrupted
Lateral process of malleus becomes more prominent

questions.text: Features of moderately retracted tympanic membrane are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Shiny pearly white tympanic membrane) because a moderately retracted tympanic membrane (TM) typically appears dull, opaque, or even atrophic, rather than its normal shiny, pearly white appearance. A healthy tympanic membrane is described as shiny, pearly white, and translucent with a well-defined cone of light. In moderate retraction, the TM loses its normal luster and appears dull or opaque due to negative middle ear pressure. Retraction occurs due to Eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to a vacuum effect in the middle ear, pulling the TM inward. Incorrect Options: Option A (Handle of Malleus Appears Foreshortened) When the TM retracts, the angle of the malleus changes, making the handle appear shorter than normal. This happens because the umbo (where the malleus attaches to the TM) gets displaced posteriorly. Option B (Cone of Light is Absent or Interrupted) Normally, the cone of light is a triangular reflection of light on the anteroinferior quadrant of the TM. Retraction distorts the TM, disrupting or completely abolishing the cone of light. Option C (Lateral Process of Malleus Becomes More Prominent) The lateral process of the malleus is normally visible, but in retraction, it becomes more prominent because the TM gets pulled inward, altering its curvature.

questions.text: Portion of middle ear around the tympanic orifice of Eustachian tube is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Planes extended from the tympanic annulus subdivide the tympanic cavity into a mesotympanum, hypotympanum, protympanum, and posterior tympanic cavity. (B) The epitympanum lies above the plane of the anterior and posterior tympanic spines. (D) Portion of middle ear around the tympanic orifice of Eustachian tube is protympanum. The tympanic cavity is in continuity with the eustachian tube anteriorly and with the mastoid air cells via the aditus and antrum. It is traversed by the ossicular chain and is lined with a mucosal epithelium.

choices.text: About half as long as in the adults
The osseous portion is longer than the cartilagenous portion
It is shorter, horizontal, and wider than that of adults
The tensor veli palatini muscle is more efficient in infants.

questions.text: Infant Eustachian tube is characterized by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (The tensor veli palatini muscle is more efficient in infants) because, in infants, the tensor veli palatini muscle is less efficient compared to adults. This muscle plays a crucial role in actively opening the Eustachian tube, but due to the anatomical differences in infants, it does not function as effectively as in adults. Incorrect Options: The tensor veli palatini muscle is responsible for opening the Eustachian tube during swallowing and yawning. In infants, the Eustachian tube is shorter, wider, and more horizontal, making it easier for infections to travel from the nasopharynx to the middle ear. Due to these structural differences, the tensor veli palatini muscle does not work as efficiently as it does in adults. This contributes to the higher incidence of otitis media in infants because the Eustachian tube does not drain efficiently. Why the Other Options Are Correct? Option A (About half as long as in adults) In infants, the Eustachian tube is approximately 18 mm long, while in adults, it is about 36 mm. This makes the infant's tube half the length of an adult's Eustachian tube. Option B (The osseous portion is longer than the cartilaginous portion) In adults, the Eustachian tube is one-third bony (osseous) and two-thirds cartilaginous. In infants, however, the bony portion is longer than the cartilaginous portion, which contributes to its horizontal orientation. Option C (It is shorter, horizontal, and wider than in adults) The infant’s Eustachian tube is shorter, more horizontal, and wider, which increases the risk of middle ear infections due to easier pathogen migration from the nasopharynx. As the child grows, the tube becomes longer, more angled (about 45°), and narrower, improving drainage and reducing infections.

questions.text: Sinus tympani is bounded by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Subiculum below and Ponticulus above) because the sinus tympani is a recess in the posterior wall of the middle ear that is anatomically bounded by the subiculum inferiorly and the ponticulus superiorly. The sinus tympani is a deep groove or recess located in the posterior tympanic cavity near the round window. It is bounded by: Ponticulus (above) – A bony ridge that separates the sinus tympani from the facial recess. Subiculum (below) – A bony ridge that separates the sinus tympani from the round window niche. This anatomical location makes the sinus tympani difficult to visualize during ear surgeries, especially in cholesteatoma and chronic otitis media cases. Incorrect Options: Option A (Only Subiculum) The subiculum is only the inferior boundary of the sinus tympani. The superior boundary is the ponticulus, so this option is incomplete. Option B (Only Ponticulus) The ponticulus is the upper boundary of the sinus tympani. The subiculum also plays a role as the lower boundary, making this option incorrect. Option C (Subiculum above and Ponticulus below) This is a reversed anatomical relationship. Ponticulus is above, and Subiculum is below, not the other way around.

questions.text: Korner’s septum is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Petrosquamous suture) because Körner’s septum is a remnant of the petrosquamous suture, which separates the petrous and squamous portions of the temporal bone. Körner’s septum is an embryological remnant of the petrosquamous suture. It is a thin bony plate located within the mastoid air cells. This septum may persist in some individuals, dividing the mastoid air cells into superficial (squamous) and deep (petrous) compartments. Its presence is clinically significant because it can: Mimic chronic mastoiditis on imaging (due to improper pneumatization). Hinder complete drainage in mastoidectomy procedures. Incorrect Options: Option B (Petrotemporal suture) The petrotemporal suture is not a recognized anatomical term in relation to Körner’s septum. Option C (Temporosquamous suture) The temporosquamous suture lies between the squamous part of the temporal bone and the parietal bone, not the petrous part. It is unrelated to Körner’s septum. Option D (None) Körner’s septum is definitely associated with the petrosquamous suture, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Most susceptible ossicle in chronic suppurative otitis media is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Long process of incus) because the long process of the incus is the most susceptible part to necrosis in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) due to its poor vascular supply and direct exposure to infection. Why is Option C Correct? The long process of the incus has a delicate blood supply, making it highly prone to ischemia and necrosis in cases of chronic infections like CSOM. In atticoantral disease (cholesteatoma-related CSOM), cholesteatoma erodes the ossicular chain, with the long process of the incus being the most affected. When the long process of the incus is eroded, it results in a discontinuity of the ossicular chain, leading to conductive hearing loss. Incus interposition surgery or ossicular chain reconstruction may be required to restore hearing. Incorrect Options: Option A (Neck of malleus) The neck of the malleus is more resistant to necrosis because it has a better vascular supply compared to the long process of the incus. Although it can be affected in advanced cases, it is less commonly involved than the incus. Option B (Short process of incus) The short process of the incus is rarely affected because it is closer to the body of the incus, which has a better blood supply. It is less vulnerable compared to the long process of the incus. Option D (Neck of stapes) The stapes is the least affected ossicle in CSOM due to its protected location in the oval window. The neck of the stapes is rarely eroded unless there is an extensive destructive process like cholesteatoma.

choices.text: Spinal assessory nerve and sympathetic fibres.

questions.text: Tympanic plexus is formed by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Glossopharyngeal nerve and sympathetic fibers) because the tympanic plexus is primarily formed by branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and sympathetic fibers from the carotid plexus. The tympanic plexus is located on the promontory of the middle ear and plays a role in innervating the mucosa of the middle ear, mastoid air cells, and Eustachian tube. It is primarily formed by: Tympanic nerve (Jacobson’s nerve) – A branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). Sympathetic fibers – Derived from the carotid plexus (postganglionic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion). The tympanic plexus also gives rise to the lesser petrosal nerve, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion, responsible for parotid gland secretion. Incorrect Options: Option A (Spinal accessory nerve and sympathetic fibers) The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) is a motor nerve that supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. It does not contribute to the tympanic plexus. Option B (Vagus nerve and sympathetic fibers) The vagus nerve (CN X) primarily supplies the larynx, pharynx, and thoracic/abdominal organs. It does not form the tympanic plexus. Option D (Arnold’s nerve and sympathetic fibers) Arnold’s nerve (Auricular branch of the vagus nerve) mainly provides sensory innervation to parts of the external ear and external auditory canal. It does not participate in forming the tympanic plexus.

choices.text: Pseudostratified columnar in bony part and columnar in cartilaginous.
Pseudostratified columnar in both cartilaginous and bony part .
Columnar in both cartilaginous and bony part .
Pseudostratified columnar in cartilaginous part and columnar in bony.

questions.text: Eustachian tube is lined by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Pseudostratified columnar in cartilaginous part and columnar in bony part) because the epithelial lining of the Eustachian tube varies between its cartilaginous and bony portions. The Eustachian tube (auditory tube) connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx and has both cartilaginous (anterior) and bony (posterior) portions. Cartilaginous part (anteromedial 2/3rd) Lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (similar to the respiratory tract). Contains goblet cells, which help in mucociliary clearance to drain secretions from the middle ear. Bony part (posterolateral 1/3rd) Lined by simple columnar epithelium. Lacks cilia and goblet cells. Less involved in active mucociliary clearance. Incorrect Options: Option A (Pseudostratified columnar in bony part and columnar in cartilaginous part) The bony part is lined by simple columnar epithelium, not pseudostratified columnar epithelium. Option B (Pseudostratified columnar in both cartilaginous and bony part) The bony part lacks pseudostratified columnar epithelium; instead, it has simple columnar epithelium. Option C (Columnar in both cartilaginous and bony part) The cartilaginous part has pseudostratified columnar epithelium with cilia, while the bony part has simple columnar epithelium.

questions.text: Patulous eustachian tube seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Pregnancy) because a patulous Eustachian tube (ET) occurs when the tube remains abnormally open, leading to autophony (hearing one's own voice and breathing loudly), which is commonly seen in pregnancy due to hormonal and weight-related changes. Pregnancy can cause a patulous Eustachian tube due to: Hormonal changes (estrogen and progesterone effects) leading to mucosal atrophy and relaxation of the Eustachian tube muscles. Weight loss during pregnancy, which reduces peritubal fat, making the tube more open. Symptoms include autophony, aural fullness, and a "hollow" voice sensation. Incorrect Options: Option B (Cleft Palate) Cleft palate is associated with Eustachian tube dysfunction (ETD), but usually leads to a blocked (hypofunctioning) Eustachian tube, not a patulous one. This results in recurrent otitis media with effusion (OME) due to poor ventilation of the middle ear. Option C (Down Syndrome) Individuals with Down syndrome have hypoplastic Eustachian tubes, leading to poor drainage and recurrent ear infections, but not patulous ET. Option D (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media - ASOM) ASOM is an infectious condition causing Eustachian tube obstruction due to inflammation and pus accumulation. It is not associated with a patulous (open) Eustachian tube.

questions.text: Prussak’s space is bounded below by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Malleus) because Prussak’s space is an important area in the epitympanum (attic) of the middle ear and is bounded inferiorly by the neck of the malleus. Prussak’s space is a small recess in the epitympanic region of the middle ear, located between the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane and the neck of the malleus. It is clinically significant because it is a common site for the development of acquired cholesteatoma due to its poor drainage. Boundaries of Prussak’s space: Superior (Above): Lateral malleolar fold Inferior (Below): Neck of the malleus Medial (Inner side): Lateral process of the malleus and pars tensa Lateral (Outer side): Shrapnell’s membrane (Pars flaccida) Incorrect Options: Option A (Fibers of lateral malleolar fold) The lateral malleolar fold forms the superior boundary, not the inferior boundary. Option B (Shrapnell’s membrane) Shrapnell’s membrane (pars flaccida) forms the lateral boundary, not the inferior boundary. Option D (Incus) The incus is located more medially and does not form the inferior boundary of Prussak’s space.

questions.text: What is the type of joint between the ossicles of bear:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Synovial joint) because the joints between the auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes) in the middle ear are synovial joints, which allow minimal movement for sound conduction. Why is Option D Correct? The ossicular chain consists of three tiny bones—malleus, incus, and stapes—that transmit sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear. The joints between these ossicles are: Incudomalleolar joint (between malleus and incus) ? Synovial saddle joint Incudostapedial joint (between incus and stapes) ? Synovial ball-and-socket joint These synovial articulations allow the ossicles to move slightly, amplifying sound vibrations for transmission to the oval window of the cochlea. Incorrect Options: Option A (Fibrous joint) Fibrous joints are immovable and found in structures like the skull sutures, whereas the ossicular joints require movement for sound conduction. Option B (Primary cartilaginous joint) Primary cartilaginous joints (synchondroses) are found in areas like growth plates and the first sternocostal joint. They do not allow significant movement, unlike the ossicular synovial joints. Option C (Secondary cartilaginous joint) Secondary cartilaginous joints (symphyses) are found in the intervertebral discs and pubic symphysis, providing strength with slight flexibility. The ossicles require a different type of articulation for effective sound transmission.

choices.text: Extradural abscess is most common complication
Combined approach tympanoplasty is canal wall up procedure
Tober Ayer sign is an CT finding
Patient is suffering from serous otitis media

questions.text: Study the given image and choose the most appropriate statement
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Combined approach tympanoplasty is a canal wall up procedure). Combined approach tympanoplasty (CAT) is a "canal wall up" (CWU) technique used for cholesteatoma surgery. It involves both retroauricular (mastoid) and transcanal approaches while preserving the posterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC). The goal is to remove disease while maintaining the natural structure of the ear, which helps with hearing preservation and easier postoperative care. In contrast, a "canal wall down" (CWD) procedure involves removing the posterior canal wall, creating an open mastoid cavity that requires lifelong cleaning. Incorrect Options: Option A (Extradural abscess is the most common complication) The most common complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with cholesteatoma is mastoiditis or labyrinthitis rather than extradural abscess. While extradural abscess can occur as a complication, it is not the most common one. Option C (Tober Ayer sign is a CT finding) Tobey-Ayer sign is NOT a CT finding but a clinical test related to lateral sinus thrombosis. It refers to an increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure in the lumbar puncture when the jugular vein is compressed on the affected side. Option D (Patient is suffering from serous otitis media) Serous otitis media (SOM) is a non-infectious condition with fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane, usually appearing as a clear, yellowish, or air-fluid level without inflammation. The image likely shows findings of chronic otitis media with cholesteatoma, which has different characteristics, including a retracted tympanic membrane, debris, or bony erosion.

choices.text: Rinne - Positive on the affected side
Weber - Lateralised to the diseased ear
Pure Tone audiometry show conductive hearing loss.
The hearing loss is invariably under 40 dB.

questions.text: All of the following are features of CSOM except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rinne - Positive on the affected side. This statement is incorrect because a positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is better than bone conduction, which is a feature of a normal ear or sensorineural hearing loss. Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) causes a conductive hearing loss, where the sound is not effectively transmitted through the middle ear. Therefore, in a patient with CSOM, the Rinne test on the affected ear would be negative, meaning bone conduction is better than air conduction. The presence of a positive Rinne test would rule out a conductive hearing loss.

choices.text: Malleus and foot plate of stapes present

questions.text: Group A of ‘Austin Kartush classification’ includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Malleus and stapes present) because Group A of the Austin-Kartush classification refers to ossicular chain defects where both the malleus and stapes are intact. Austin-Kartush classification is used to categorize ossicular chain defects based on which ossicles are present or absent in chronic otitis media, trauma, or cholesteatoma surgeries. Group A is defined as: Malleus present Stapes suprastructure present Incus missing or eroded Ideal scenario for ossiculoplasty using incus interposition or prosthesis This group offers a good prognosis for hearing restoration since the malleus and stapes provide stable anchoring points for ossicular reconstruction. Incorrect Options: Option B (Malleus and footplate of stapes present) If only the stapes footplate is present (without the suprastructure), it falls under Group C or D, depending on malleus status. This condition requires a different type of ossiculoplasty, such as a total ossicular replacement prosthesis (TORP). Option C (Malleus absent and stapes present) If the malleus is absent but the stapes is present, it falls under Group B of the classification. This scenario is less favorable for hearing outcomes compared to Group A. Option D (Malleus and stapes suprastructure absent) If both the malleus and stapes suprastructure are absent, it falls under Group D. Hearing reconstruction is most challenging in this category and typically requires a TORP (Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis)

questions.text: Wullstein classification is used for tubotympanic ear,Considering the classification ‘Columella tympanoplasty’ is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Type III tympanoplasty) because Columella tympanoplasty is classified as Type III in Wullstein’s classification. This type of tympanoplasty is performed when the ossicular chain is disrupted, but the stapes suprastructure is intact. In this procedure, the tympanic membrane is directly placed over the stapes head, creating a columella effect, which helps in sound transmission. Incorrect Options: Option A (Type I Tympanoplasty) Type I tympanoplasty is myringoplasty, where only the tympanic membrane is repaired. Ossicular chain remains intact and functional, unlike in columella tympanoplasty (Type III), where there is ossicular discontinuity. Option B (Type II Tympanoplasty) In Type II tympanoplasty, there is partial ossicular damage, usually involving the incus. The tympanic membrane is repaired and connected to the remaining part of the ossicular chain (such as the malleus or stapes suprastructure). In contrast, Type III (Columella tympanoplasty) involves placing the tympanic membrane directly over the stapes. Option D (Type IV Tympanoplasty) Type IV tympanoplasty is performed when only the stapes footplate is present, and the suprastructure is absent. The tympanic membrane is placed directly over the oval window to help in sound conduction. Columella tympanoplasty (Type III) retains the stapes suprastructure, unlike Type IV.

questions.text: A 7 year old male presents to the ER with a two day history of worsening ear pain and discharge. On the day prior to presentation, his parents noted redness behind his right ear, and that his right ear appeared to be sticking out. He had been well until 10 days ago when he started complaining of a cough and runny nose that progressed to include right ear pain and fever. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with an acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing up and out. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Mastoiditis) because the child exhibits classic signs of acute mastoiditis, including: Persistent ear pain and discharge despite antibiotic treatment for acute otitis media (AOM) Postauricular redness, swelling, and tenderness Protrusion of the pinna (ear sticking out and pointing up and out) History of preceding AOM that initially improved but then worsened Mastoiditis is a common complication of untreated or inadequately treated acute otitis media, where the infection spreads from the middle ear to the mastoid air cells, leading to inflammation and possible abscess formation. Incorrect Options: Option A (Otitis Externa) Otitis externa (swimmer’s ear) is an infection of the external auditory canal, causing pain, itching, and tenderness with tragal manipulation. It does not cause postauricular swelling, pinna protrusion, or fever, making it unlikely in this case. Option B (Otitis Media with Effusion) Otitis media with effusion (OME) refers to fluid accumulation in the middle ear without acute infection. It typically presents with ear fullness, hearing loss, and no fever or discharge. This patient has fever, ear pain, and postauricular swelling, which are not features of OME. Option D (Allergic Otitis Media) Allergic otitis media occurs due to eustachian tube dysfunction caused by allergies. It leads to chronic serous effusion in the middle ear but does not cause fever, ear discharge, or postauricular swelling.

choices.text: Retracted TM touching incus or stapes
TM touching promontory but moves on seigelisation
TM touching promontory, does not move

questions.text: Sade classification is related with retraction of pars tensa.Grade 2 includes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Sade classification is used to grade the retraction of the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane (TM) based on severity. Grade 1: Mild retraction of TM Grade 2: TM is retracted and touching the incus or stapes (Correct Answer: B) Grade 3: TM is touching the promontory but moves with Siegelization (pneumatic otoscopy) Grade 4: TM is adherent to the promontory and does not move with Siegelization Incorrect Options: Option A (Mild retraction) Mild retraction is Grade 1, where TM is pulled slightly inward but not touching any ossicles. Option C (TM touching promontory but moves on Siegelization) This describes Grade 3, where the TM contacts the promontory but is still mobile with Siegelization. Option D (TM touching promontory, does not move) This represents Grade 4, where the TM is firmly adherent to the promontory and is immobile even with Siegelization.

choices.text: Stapes defect with fixation of footplate and lenticular process involvement

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital ossicular dysfunction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most common type of congenital ossicular dysfunction is stapes defect with fixation of the footplate and lenticular process involvement (Correct Answer: B). This condition leads to conductive hearing loss as the stapes cannot properly transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear. Stapes fixation may occur due to abnormal ossification or congenital malformations. Lenticular process involvement further worsens sound conduction by disrupting the incudostapedial joint, impairing the movement of the ossicular chain. Incorrect Options: Option A (Isolated stapes defect) While stapes anomalies are common, an isolated stapes defect without footplate fixation is less frequent than combined stapes and footplate abnormalities. Option C (Defective lenticular process of incus) Isolated lenticular process defects occur but are less common compared to stapes defects with footplate fixation. This condition may cause ossicular discontinuity, leading to conductive hearing loss. Option D (None of the above) Since Option B correctly describes the most common congenital ossicular dysfunction, Option D is not applicable.

questions.text: Most common intracranial complication of CSOM is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common intracranial complication of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) is Meningitis (Correct Answer: A). Meningitis occurs when the infection spreads from the middle ear or mastoid to the meninges through direct bone erosion or hematogenous spread. It is particularly common in children and presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and photophobia. The most frequently involved bacteria include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Incorrect Options: Option B (Brain Abscess) Brain abscess is a serious intracranial complication of CSOM but is less common than meningitis. It results from direct extension of the infection or hematogenous spread, commonly affecting the temporal lobe or cerebellum. Option C (Lateral Sinus Thrombosis) Lateral sinus thrombosis occurs due to infection of the sigmoid sinus but is less frequent than meningitis. It may present with septicemia, headache, papilledema, and a classical "picket fence" fever pattern. Option D (Subdural Abscess) Subdural abscess is a rare but severe complication of CSOM, occurring when infection spreads into the subdural space. It can lead to neurological deficits, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Infection of CNS spreads to middle ear through:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fissure of Hyrtl's because it serves as a potential route for infection spread from the central nervous system (CNS) to the middle ear. The fissure of Hyrtl is a congenital bony defect in the floor of the hypotympanum that connects the middle ear with the jugular fossa. This pathway allows the spread of meningitis, brain abscess, or other CNS infections into the middle ear, leading to otogenic complications. Incorrect Options: Option A (Cochlear Aqueduct) The cochlear aqueduct connects the perilymphatic space of the cochlea to the subarachnoid space. While it allows the spread of infections (e.g., meningitis) from the inner ear to the CNS, it does not directly transmit infections from the CNS to the middle ear. Option B (Endolymphatic Sac) The endolymphatic sac is part of the vestibular system and is mainly involved in endolymph homeostasis. It does not play a significant role in the spread of infection between the CNS and the middle ear. Option C (Lymphatic Route) Lymphatic drainage of the ear is mainly via the retroauricular, parotid, and deep cervical lymph nodes. Infection can spread via lymphatics, but it is not a primary or direct pathway for CNS infections reaching the middle ear

questions.text: Light house sign is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) because the Lighthouse sign is a clinical feature observed in ASOM with tympanic membrane perforation. The Lighthouse sign refers to intermittent otorrhea (ear discharge) that appears and disappears rhythmically with breathing or changes in pressure, resembling the flashing light of a lighthouse. This occurs due to pulsatile movement of pus through a perforation in the tympanic membrane, commonly seen in ASOM. Incorrect Options: Option A (Serous Otitis Media) Serous otitis media (also known as otitis media with effusion) is characterized by fluid accumulation behind an intact tympanic membrane without active infection or perforation. Since there is no tympanic membrane perforation, the Lighthouse sign is not seen in this condition. Option C (Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media - CSOM) While CSOM also involves persistent tympanic membrane perforation and discharge, it does not typically show the rhythmic, pulsatile discharge seen in ASOM. The infection in CSOM is chronic, and the otorrhea is usually continuous rather than intermittent. Option D (Otic Hydrocephalus) Otic hydrocephalus is a condition where increased intracranial pressure occurs due to chronic ear infections affecting the venous drainage of the brain. This condition does not present with tympanic membrane perforation or intermittent ear discharge, making Lighthouse sign irrelevant.

questions.text: The brown sign is seen in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glomus Tumor because the Brown sign is a characteristic clinical feature of glomus tumors in the middle ear. Brown sign refers to blanching (temporary paleness) of a reddish middle ear mass when pressure is applied to the external auditory canal. This occurs because glomus tumors are highly vascular, and pressure temporarily reduces the blood flow to the tumor, causing it to blanch. Incorrect Options: Option B (Ménière’s Disease) Ménière’s disease is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by episodic vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss, and ear fullness. It is unrelated to vascular tumors, and the Brown sign is not seen in this condition. Option C (Acoustic Neuroma) Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). It presents with gradual sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues, but not with a vascular middle ear mass or the Brown sign. Option D (Otosclerosis) Otosclerosis is a progressive fixation of the stapes bone, leading to conductive hearing loss. It does not involve a vascular tumor or show tumor blanching with pressure.

questions.text: A 5 year old patient presents with the history of hearing loss. On examination he is found to have a pearly white mass behind the intact tympanic membrane.What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Congenital Cholesteatoma because the presence of a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with hearing loss is the classic presentation of this condition. Congenital cholesteatoma is a benign but locally destructive growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium within the middle ear or temporal bone. It arises without a history of tympanic membrane perforation, otorrhea, or previous ear infections. The mass is often found in the anterior superior quadrant of the middle ear. Symptoms include progressive conductive hearing loss due to ossicular chain involvement. Incorrect Options: Option B (Otomycosis) Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external auditory canal, presenting with itching, pain, and fungal debris (black or white fluffy discharge). It does not cause a pearly white mass behind the tympanic membrane. Option C (Otosclerosis) Otosclerosis is a progressive fixation of the stapes bone due to abnormal bone remodeling. It leads to conductive hearing loss but does not present as a visible mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. Typically affects adults or young adults, not a 5-year-old child. Option D (Exostosis) Exostosis (surfer’s ear) is the bony overgrowth of the external auditory canal due to chronic cold water exposure. It does not cause a middle ear mass or conductive hearing loss in a child.

questions.text: A child presents with ear infection with foul smelling discharge.On futher exploration a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.Most appropriate next step in the management would be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mastoid Exploration because the presence of a foul-smelling ear discharge with a small perforation in the pars flaccida strongly suggests atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with cholesteatoma. This condition can lead to serious complications such as mastoiditis, intracranial infections, and ossicular destruction, requiring surgical intervention. Atticoantral CSOM (also called unsafe CSOM) is associated with cholesteatoma, a destructive keratinizing lesion that erodes the middle ear structures. A small perforation in the pars flaccida is a key finding in cholesteatoma, which requires surgical management to prevent further complications. Mastoid exploration (including canal wall up or down mastoidectomy) is the preferred treatment to remove the disease and prevent complications. Incorrect Options: Option A (Tympanoplasty) Tympanoplasty is not the first step in managing CSOM with cholesteatoma. Tympanoplasty alone is contraindicated in cholesteatoma without first performing mastoid exploration to remove the disease. Option B (Topical Antibiotics) Topical antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin ear drops) can help control infection but do not treat cholesteatoma. This would be an inadequate treatment as cholesteatoma is a progressive and potentially dangerous condition. Option C (I.V. Antibiotics) IV antibiotics may be useful only if there is a spreading infection (e.g., acute mastoiditis or intracranial extension).

questions.text: 25 yrs old ramesh presented with irregular fever having one or more peaks in a day,headache and general weakness.Local examination reveals tenderness over mastoid. External compression of jugular vein results in no rise in CSF,patient was suffering from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral Sinus Thrombophlebitis because the patient presents with: Irregular fever with multiple peaks in a day (picket fence fever pattern) – characteristic of septic thrombophlebitis. Headache, general weakness, and mastoid tenderness – suggestive of a complication of chronic otitis media or mastoiditis. Negative Queckenstedt’s Test (External jugular vein compression does not raise CSF pressure) – a classic sign of lateral sinus thrombosis. Lateral sinus thrombosis occurs as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) and mastoiditis, where infection spreads to the sigmoid sinus, leading to clot formation, venous congestion, and systemic septicemia. Incorrect Options: Option B (Otitic Hydrocephalus) Otitic hydrocephalus presents with raised intracranial pressure (ICP), papilledema, and CSF pressure rise on Queckenstedt’s test. In this case, Queckenstedt’s test is negative, ruling out otitic hydrocephalus. Option C (Subacute Mastoiditis) Subacute mastoiditis can cause mastoid tenderness and fever, but it does not explain the irregular fever pattern or negative Queckenstedt’s test. Also, mastoiditis itself is usually a precursor to lateral sinus thrombosis, rather than an alternative diagnosis. Option D (Labyrinthine Fistula) Labyrinthine fistula presents with vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and positive fistula test (pressure-induced vertigo and nystagmus). The patient’s symptoms suggest systemic sepsis and venous thrombosis rather than inner ear involvement.

questions.text: “Invagination of TM from attic part of pars tensa is form of retraction pocket” is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Wittmaack’s theory because this theory describes the invagination (retraction) of the tympanic membrane (TM) from the attic part of the pars tensa, forming a retraction pocket. Wittmaack proposed that chronic negative pressure in the middle ear, due to Eustachian tube dysfunction, leads to progressive retraction of the tympanic membrane, particularly in the attic region (pars flaccida), which may later develop into a cholesteatoma. Incorrect Options: Option A (Ruedi’s theory) Ruedi’s theory suggests that congenital epidermoid formation in the middle ear leads to the development of cholesteatoma, rather than retraction pockets. Option C (Habermann’s theory) Habermann’s theory states that inflammatory hyperplasia of epithelial cells in the middle ear forms cholesteatoma rather than from a retraction pocket. Option D (Sade’s theory) Sade’s theory classifies tympanic membrane retraction based on severity, but it does not specifically state that invagination from the attic is the mechanism for retraction pocket formation.

questions.text: All of the given features suggest unsafe CSOM except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Profuse discharge because profuse discharge alone does not necessarily indicate unsafe chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). While unsafe CSOM (atticoantral type) is commonly associated with scanty, foul-smelling discharge due to cholesteatoma, profuse discharge is more characteristic of safe (tubotympanic) CSOM, which does not pose the same risk of complications. Incorrect Options: Option B (Fleshy polyp) – Suggests Unsafe CSOM A fleshy polyp in the external auditory canal often originates from granulation tissue associated with cholesteatoma, which is a hallmark of unsafe CSOM. Option C (Mixed deafness) – Suggests Unsafe CSOM Unsafe CSOM can erode the ossicles and bony labyrinth, leading to both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss (mixed deafness). Safe CSOM usually causes only conductive hearing loss. Option D (Attic perforation) – Suggests Unsafe CSOM Perforation in the attic (pars flaccida) is a defining feature of unsafe CSOM because it is strongly associated with cholesteatoma formation, which can cause serious complications like bone erosion and intracranial infections.

choices.text: Biopsy is avoided in this patient

questions.text: All are clinically applicable statements to glomus Jugulare except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intralesional Bleomycin is standard therapy because intralesional Bleomycin is not considered a standard treatment for glomus jugulare tumors. The mainstay of treatment includes surgical excision, radiotherapy, and sometimes embolization to reduce vascularity before surgery. While Bleomycin has been explored for vascular tumors like hemangiomas, it is not a recognized standard therapy for glomus jugulare. Incorrect Options: Option B (Erosion of caroticojugular spine) Glomus jugulare tumors arise from the paraganglia of the jugular bulb and frequently erode the caroticojugular spine, which is visible on imaging studies such as CT or MRI. This bony erosion contributes to skull base involvement and neurological deficits affecting lower cranial nerves (IX, X, XI). Option C (Biopsy is avoided in this patient) Biopsy is contraindicated because glomus jugulare tumors are highly vascular tumors. A biopsy can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage, so diagnosis is primarily based on clinical evaluation and imaging (MRI with contrast, CT, and angiography). Option D (Brown sign on pneumatic otoscopy) The Brown sign refers to blanching of the vascular mass when positive pressure is applied to the tympanic membrane using a pneumatic otoscope. It occurs due to temporary compression of blood flow within the tumor and is a characteristic finding in glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum tumors.

questions.text: Which is not found on the medial wall of middle ear
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Facial Recess, as it is not located on the medial wall of the middle ear. Instead, the facial recess is a posterior structure found in the posterior wall of the middle ear, between the facial nerve and the chorda tympani nerve. It is an important surgical landmark in mastoidectomy and cochlear implant surgery. Incorrect Options: Option A (Processus Cochleariformis) – Present on Medial Wall The processus cochleariformis is a bony projection of the medial wall of the middle ear. It serves as a pulley for the tendon of the tensor tympani muscle, which controls tension in the tympanic membrane. Option C (Secondary Tympanic Membrane) – Present on Medial Wall The secondary tympanic membrane covers the round window, which is a key feature of the medial wall. It plays a role in sound wave dissipation to allow movement of the perilymph within the cochlea. Option D (Subiculum) – Present on Medial Wall The subiculum is a bony ridge on the medial wall that forms the lower boundary of the sinus tympani. It is significant in ear surgery as sinus tympani is a potential site for cholesteatoma and difficult to visualize.
